courses.name: Art and Ideas

cmCourseInfo.description: A survey of the history of art, architecture and allied arts. This introduction to the history of art will examine a wide range of objects, selected and discussed in connection with a special theme to be selected by the instructor. Students will be expected to study the history and significance of art through the close reading of selected texts that relate to both art and theory. Special attention will be given to developing essential art historical skills necessary for upper level courses. The topic for each semester will vary based on the instructor. No previous knowledge of history of art or architecture is required. Frequent writing assignments and exercises will be based on readings, lectures, and museum or gallery visits to collections in Toronto.
cmCourseInfo.title: Art and Ideas

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This introduction to the history of art will examine a wide range of art and related practices, selected and discussed in connection with a special theme chosen by the instructor, 'Art & Nature in the Anthropocene.' With an emphasis on the visual arts in the Western tradition from c. 1500 to the present, we will discuss central movements, pivotal artists and works, and issues through the rubric of art's many relationships with the terrestrial. Students will also study the history and significance of art and visual culture through the close reading of assigned texts that relate to both art and theory. Special attention will be given to developing the art historical skills necessary for upper level courses and for writing in this field.

courses.name: Art and Ideas

cmCourseInfo.description: A survey of the history of art, architecture and allied arts. This introduction to the history of art will examine a wide range of objects, selected and discussed in connection with a special theme to be selected by the instructor. Students will be expected to study the history and significance of art through the close reading of selected texts that relate to both art and theory. Special attention will be given to developing essential art historical skills necessary for upper level courses. The topic for each semester will vary based on the instructor. No previous knowledge of history of art or architecture is required. Frequent writing assignments and exercises will be based on readings, lectures, and museum or gallery visits to collections in Toronto.
cmCourseInfo.title: Art and Ideas

courses.name: Prehistoric Aegean and East Mediterranean Art and Archaeology

cmCourseInfo.description: An overview of the major monuments, artifacts, themes and problems in the study of the archaeology, art and architecture of the Aegean region and the east Mediterranean to 1000BC.
cmCourseInfo.title: Prehistoric Aegean and East Mediterranean Art and Archaeology

courses.name: Greek and Roman Art and Archaeology

cmCourseInfo.description: An overview of the major monuments, artifacts, themes and problems in the study of the archaeology, art and architecture of the civilizations of Greece and Rome.
cmCourseInfo.title: Greek and Roman Art and Archaeology

courses.name: Early Medieval Art and Architecture

cmCourseInfo.description: An overview of major monuments and themes in the art and architecture of Western Europe and the Byzantine East from the third until the eleventh century.
cmCourseInfo.title: Early Medieval Art and Architecture

courses.name: Baroque Art and Architecture (formerly FAH279H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: Major forms of expression in the visual arts ca. 1600 - ca. 1750 with particular attention to forms, techniques, theories, and patronage of the arts as well as biographies of artists in Italy, France, the Netherlands, Flanders, Germany and England.
cmCourseInfo.title: Baroque Art and Architecture (formerly FAH279H1)

courses.name: Art Since 1900

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to the consolidation of Modernist tendencies in Europe to the mid 20th century and to the many contemporary responses to these achievements. Individual artists, including Picasso, Matisse, Duchamp, and Matthew Barney are considered in their relationship to various art movements and the theories that supported them, including Expressionism; Abstraction and Constructivism; Dada and Surrealism; Neue Sachlichkeit; Abstract Expressionism; Pop; Conceptual Art; Earth Art; Feminist Art; Postmodernism; New Media Art.
cmCourseInfo.title: Art Since 1900

courses.name: Introduction to the History of Photography

cmCourseInfo.description: This course surveys the history of photography in Europe and North America, from its origins to recent innovations in digital imaging.  Emphasis is placed on the various aesthetic, scientific, and political discourses in which photography has been located, and the assumptions and premises associated with the medium's relationship to reality.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to the History of Photography

courses.name: The Artistic Landscape of East Asia (formerly FAH290H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: An overview of major monuments and themes in the art and architecture of East Asia (China, Japan, Korea, Vietnam, Mongolia and Tibet), from the neolithic to the present.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Artistic Landscape of East Asia (formerly FAH290H1)

courses.name: Modern Architecture from 1750 to the Present

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to the buildings, issues and ideas from Neoclassicism to the present.
cmCourseInfo.title: Modern Architecture from 1750 to the Present

courses.name: City of Rome

cmCourseInfo.description: The art, architecture and archaeology of the city of Rome to AD476.
cmCourseInfo.title: City of Rome

courses.name: Greek Vase Painting

cmCourseInfo.description: This course is a comprehensive exploration of the art of Greek vase painting, covering material from the late Geometric period (8th C. BCE) to the late Classical Period (4th C. BCE). While iconography and narrative will form a major portion of the ceontent, the class will also explore issues surrounding material and technique, the prevalent sympotic (drinking) culture and Greek rituals that provides the cultural framework, dynamics of trade, theories of viewership and semiotics, status of the artist, and other historiographical concerns, including problematic issues surrounding the modern practice of collecting.
cmCourseInfo.title: Greek Vase Painting

courses.name: Greek Myth in Ancient Art

cmCourseInfo.description: A general introduction to Greek mythology and its uses (and abuses) by the Greeks and Romans through the art of antiquity. Students will learn about gods and goddesses, heroes and heroines, their attributes and stories which constituted the subjects of (not only) ancient art.
cmCourseInfo.title: Greek Myth in Ancient Art

courses.name: Monastic Art and Architecture

cmCourseInfo.description: An examination of the role played by monks and nuns in the creation and use of art and architecture in the Middle Ages.
cmCourseInfo.title: Monastic Art and Architecture

courses.name: Illuminated Manuscripts

cmCourseInfo.description: A focused survey of different types of manuscripts and their images from the origins of the book in Late Antiquity to the invention of printing.
cmCourseInfo.title: Illuminated Manuscripts

courses.name: Cultural History of Islamic Spain

cmCourseInfo.description: From its earliest beginnings as an Umayyad province and up until the 15th century, al-Andalus acted as a lynch pin within the Mediterranean world. Connecting the Islamic empire in the East and forging links of trade and cultural exchange with Europe to the West, cities such as Cordoba and Granada captured the imagination of contemporary chroniclers, earning descriptions in the sources as truly “first-rate places”. Through an exploration of the historical, artistic, architectural, urban, social and economic contexts, this course will engage with and expand upon current understandings of this seminal period in Islamic history to examine Islam’s encounters and modes of cultural exchange with Europe and the Mediterranean world.
cmCourseInfo.title: Cultural History of Islamic Spain
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Any Medieval 200 or 300 level half-course (any one of FAH215H1, FAH216H1, FAH318H1, FAH319H1, FAH327H1, or FAH328H1).

courses.name: Netherlandish Renaissance Art and Culture (formerly FAH307H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: Painting, sculpture and architecture of the Netherlands in the sixteenth century with reference to the arts in Italy, France, Germany and Spain. Consideration of Netherlandish art in the context of literature, religion, urban expansion, political and economic developments; and as a system of communication. Particular attention devoted to Hieronymus Bosch, Pieter Bruegel, the rise of secular art.
cmCourseInfo.title: Netherlandish Renaissance Art and Culture (formerly FAH307H1)

courses.name: Rivalry, Imitation and Envy in Italian Renaissance Art

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines works in different art media, including painting, sculpture and prints, produced from 1400 to 1600, discussing how artistic practice of imitation and emulation stimulated the development of individual styles. In addition, this course addresses notions of disruptive rivalry, and the representation of slander and envy.
cmCourseInfo.title: Rivalry, Imitation and Envy in Italian Renaissance Art

courses.name: The Dada and Surrealist Tradition (formerly FAH385H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: The origins and development of the Dada and Surrealist movements in early 20th-century Western art, and their lasting impact on art after World War II. Painting, sculpture, graphic arts, and the theoretical preoccupation which accompanied artistic production.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Dada and Surrealist Tradition (formerly FAH385H1)

courses.name: 19th Century Photography

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to the major artists, movements, and debates in photography in Europe and North America, from its prehistory to the turn of the century.  Issues considered include the relationship of social class to aesthetics, the role of illusion, the rise of mass reproduction.
cmCourseInfo.title: 19th Century Photography

courses.name: Art in Canada Since the 1960s

cmCourseInfo.description: An examination of the visual arts in Canada from the 1960’s to the present. A large and diverse range of media, practices, artists, and theoretical contexts will be examined. Emphasis is placed on work that can be seen in the original.
cmCourseInfo.title: Art in Canada Since the 1960s

courses.name: Landscape to EcoArt

cmCourseInfo.description: Ecological art is a focus in contemporary global art. We examine ecoart’s antecedents in the landscape genre and Earth Art and the diverse theoretical and disciplinary perspectives that inform our understanding of these movements. Artists include Burtynsky, Eliasson, Long, Mendieta, Netco, Smithson, Turrell. Readings include Deleuze, Heidegger, Latour.
cmCourseInfo.title: Landscape to EcoArt

courses.name: World of the Senses: Chinese Decorative Arts

cmCourseInfo.description: This course surveys late imperial Chinese decorative arts from the Song (960-1127) through Qing (1644-1911) dynasties. It focuses on ceramics/porcelain, textiles, and furniture, attending especially to works in Toronto collections. Students will read primary and secondary sources to learn how decorative arts shaped daily life in imperial China.
cmCourseInfo.title: World of the Senses: Chinese Decorative Arts
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Any 200-level FAH half course/any 100- or 200-level EAS Society-Culture course.

courses.name: Visual South Asia

cmCourseInfo.description: An overview of the visual culture (monuments to films) of South Asia form the Indus Valley Civilization (3500 BCE) to the contemporary. Focus on visual literacy, stylistic evolution, major concepts and the first-hand study of objects.
cmCourseInfo.title: Visual South Asia
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: any 200-level FAH half course / any course in Asian history, culture, or religion

courses.name: Architecture and Urbanism in Baroque Europe

cmCourseInfo.description: Architecture studied through its various building types and in its urban context. Themes include architecture and power under Absolutism, and the rise of the modern city.
cmCourseInfo.title: Architecture and Urbanism in Baroque Europe

courses.name: Studies in Roman Painting and Sculpture

cmCourseInfo.description: Issues explored might cover Republican and Imperial painting; its Hellenistic sources and parallel media (mosaic, relief). The four distinctive genres of Roman sculptural production: the portrait, the historical relief, sarcophagi, and replicas of famous Greek sculptures. Styles, themes and modes of display in cultural context.
cmCourseInfo.title: Studies in Roman Painting and Sculpture

courses.name: Studies in Medieval Book Illumination

cmCourseInfo.description: A consideration of individual types of books, their decoration, function, and cultural context. Topics might include, for example, Gospels, Psalters, or Books of Hours.
cmCourseInfo.title: Studies in Medieval Book Illumination

courses.name: Leonardo and His Legacy in Renaissance Italy

cmCourseInfo.description: This seminar examines major critical developments in the interpretation of High Renaissance art in Italy by looking at key works produced by Leonardo, his contemporaries, and followers (1470-1530).
cmCourseInfo.title: Leonardo and His Legacy in Renaissance Italy

courses.name: The First Art Historians

cmCourseInfo.description: In Vasari’s Lives of the Artists and their “after-lives,” painters and humanists explored questions of word and image, art and life, biography and history, the psychology of style, the economics and politics of art and the languages of art. How and why did art history originate?
cmCourseInfo.title: The First Art Historians

courses.name: Italian Renaissance Art, Fashion, and Material Culture

cmCourseInfo.description: This seminar explores fashion in the visual and material culture of Renaissance Italy. It focuses on the discourse of fashion as represented by Renaissance artists in their works and as treated in contemporary texts. It further examines the multiple meanings of dress in the courts of Renaissance Italy.
cmCourseInfo.title: Italian Renaissance Art, Fashion, and Material Culture

courses.name: International Art Since 1940 (formerly FAH402H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: Developments in the mainstream of Western painting and sculpture since World War II with special emphasis upon interrelations between Europe and North America.
cmCourseInfo.title: International Art Since 1940 (formerly FAH402H1)

courses.name: Issues in Canadian Art, ca. 1900-1940 (formerly FAH415H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: Focused, thematic examinations of the visual arts in Canada in the first half of the twentieth century.
cmCourseInfo.title: Issues in Canadian Art, ca. 1900-1940 (formerly FAH415H1)

courses.name: Materiality, Objecthood, Connoisseurship and Collecting in the Arts of East Asia

cmCourseInfo.description: Seminar based on firsthand examination of East Asian objects in Toronto collections that attends to the historical processes by which such objects were valued and collected.
cmCourseInfo.title: Materiality, Objecthood, Connoisseurship and Collecting in the Arts of East Asia

courses.name: Studies in Renaissance and Baroque Architecture (formerly FAH450H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: An in-depth study of themes and problems in architecture in Renaissance and Baroque Europe.
cmCourseInfo.title: Studies in Renaissance and Baroque Architecture (formerly FAH450H1)

courses.name: Studies in Modern Architecture

cmCourseInfo.description: Focused examination of themes and methods in the history of architecture since 1750.
cmCourseInfo.title: Studies in Modern Architecture

courses.name: Internship (formerly FAH455H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: The internship is designed to offer hands-on experience pertaining to the study, exhibition, and care of works of art, focused on the collections and activities of the University Art Centre, an auction house, a public museum, or a private gallery. Students must provide proof of their acceptance as an intern by the Art Centre/auction house/museum/gallery in order to be enrolled in the course. This course is Pass/Fail. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Internship (formerly FAH455H1)
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 8 FAH half courses; permission of instructor (application in department)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
To enrol in this course, please contact contact Louise Kermode at the Art Department for details, email undergrad.arthistory@utoronto.ca.

courses.name: Introduction to Conservation: Materials, Deterioration, and Preservation in Art and Material Culture (formerly FAH453H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to conservation, designed to give students a basic understanding of the field, its techniques, and its purposes. Sessions conducted by specialists in the Royal Ontario Museum conservation department.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Conservation: Materials, Deterioration, and Preservation in Art and Material Culture (formerly FAH453H1)
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 8 FAH half courses; permission of instructor.

courses.name: Collecting Canada: Canadian Pictorial Arts Collection at the Royal Ontario Museum (formerly FAH456H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: Theoretical and practical engagement with the ROM's Canadian paintings, prints and drawing collections (18th-20th C). Through lectures, workshops, and seminars, we consider the collecting, interpretation, and display of images within the framework of “documentary art” and its various connotations.
cmCourseInfo.title: Collecting Canada: Canadian Pictorial Arts Collection at the Royal Ontario Museum (formerly FAH456H1)

courses.name: Case Studies at the Royal Ontario Museum

cmCourseInfo.description: In-depth investigation of objects at the Royal Ontario Museum. Content will vary according to the museum department offering the course in any given semester.
cmCourseInfo.title: Case Studies at the Royal Ontario Museum

courses.name: Introduction to the Textile Arts of the Indian Ocean World

cmCourseInfo.description: The Indian Ocean has been called the Cradle of Globalization. For thousands of years monsoon winds linked the people and arts of this vast Ocean that stretches from East Africa in the West to Indonesia (and beyond) in the East. Throughout its long history, handwoven textiles have been amongst the area’s greatest art forms, trade goods, religious objects and markers of identity. This course will survey the wide variety of these forms, from c. 1100 to 1950. Special attention is placed on India, which lies at the center of the region, and originated many of the fibres, techniques, design and iconography of the wider area. Select regional manifestations are then examined in depth, using the ROM’s extensive collections. These range from the silks of Madagascar, to embroidered men’s wear of Oman, to the cosmopolitan batiks of northern coastal Java. It is seen that all these traditions can best be understood within the framework of the wider Indian Ocean region.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to the Textile Arts of the Indian Ocean World
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: Asian art, Islamic art, or anthropology
